comments.commentBody: Folks need to stop trying to preserve  Prince's pattern of unhealthy secrets, it is such a disservice. If Judith Hill was not in the plane Prince would have died in the air.  If Prince were not left alone on April 21 he probably would still be alive. And he would have been challenged by knowing everyone would know his best kept secret: an addiction to drugs, whatever the reason - a chink in the armor, information that could not be controlled. And I am sure those folks who are clamoring about this article would be the least supportive and most critical of his difficult path recovery from drug use and the obvious humiliation Prince would have suffered through.  Leave Judith Hill alone.  Prince's great artistry and humanity is in tact.  Appreciate the truth: Prince was human and he suffered and he is not suffering anymore.  Love Prince more than the secrets that contributed to his death.

Michael, Prince both dead. Too much privilege, too much private, too much obedience -- too much VIP for a long prior to their dying. Robert Downing Jr. Should count himself fortunate that he was arrested on numerous occasions, as well Lindsey Lohan and had to get help.

It is hurtful Prince and Michael did not recover from the grips of the prescription drugs and then able to tell that story. But no doubt they are both now at peace- say amen God has spoken.

rh,

Tolerance simply allows. People's beliefs and free speech (in this country, anyway) are tolerated, however odious other people might find them. But tolerance is not the same as acceptance; the intolerant aren't absolved of criticism because of the sincerity of their beliefs.

rh: But we can endorse Attorney General Lynch's comment:

“Let me say to our L.G.B.T. friends and family, particularly to anyone who might view this tragedy as an indication that their identities — their essential selves — might somehow be better left unexpressed or in the shadows: This Department of Justice — and your country — stands with you in the light,” she said.

I believe the age of tolerance needed to end yesterday.  Tolerance implies a cold stalemate of irreconcilable differences that breeds contempt.  Potential acts of violence loom very close beneath the veneer of tolerance.  Tolerance is the poison that causes people on the fringe to wither on the vine rather than becoming thriving members of society.  Tolerance is the ability to put up a wall and say, "you stay on your side, I'll stay on my side, and all will be okay."  That never ends well.

Can someone be tolerant of people who don't think it is okay that their son or daughter revealed their homosexuality in death?

Can people who ask others to be tolerant be tolerant of views different from their own, as long as it is from a position of unfamiliarity and culture?

At some point, there is a right to be wrong, as long as no one is hurt. Feeling bad that a relative of the deceased doesn't want to be seen on TV by their pastor or a bigoted boss shouldn't erase the rights of the relative.

Very tricky area. We cannot speak for the Dead, and we cannot speak for how people cope with Death.
Is isn't it about time that we realize that we are all people; we're all the same, gay, straight, or trans gender?

bbtoronto,

In the US, LGBT people can still be denied housing for our sexuality or gender identity. We can still be denied services. We can still be denied employment; we can even be fired for it.

Hate is still active; Orlando is proof enough of that. But there are also thousands of bias crimes a year committed against us in this country. LGBT kids are still bullied. We're still more likely to suffer from depression, anxiety, and suicide ideation. We're still disproportionately affected by HIV/AIDS.

None of these can be easily 'mopped up.' Institutional and cultural homophobia, like other forms of bigotry, is pernicious. It doesn't change overnight; it doesn't change in one generation.

And we certainly can't say to hell with potential allies. Look at North Carolina. Look at Indiana. Look at Georgia. These places don't respond to our cries for justice. However, they do, for example, respond to threats of disinvestment from the business community, and I shouldn't have to tell you that the people capable of making those threats are almost exclusively straight dudes.

Resting on our laurels, prematurely declaring "mission accomplished," is not an option. It's not even reality.

He had a legitimate chronic pain condition in his hip joints for 20 years. Although he had surgery, it did nothing to relieve his pain. He safely took opiate pain relievers for many years to manage his pain and to lead a productive life. But Prince allowed dependency on pain medication to turn to addiction. That's where the problem began and ended for him, sadly.

Until you have lived with chronic pain for months at a time, there is simply no way you can understand the need for proper pain management. It saves patients' lives, makes patients' lives more productive, and provides patients with quality of life sometimes in lieu of quantity.

Suzanne ,
Your assertion that increasing amounts of opiates are needed to garner the same effect is not always true . I am 64 and have had chronic back pain since I was 27 . I had to begin taking Vicodin daily in 1992 , almost 25 years ago . Now , as then , I take 4 to 5 per day . I do not crave the drug and only have to increase the dosage or switch to oxycodone ( Vicodin is hydrocodone w/ Tylenol ) once or twice a year for a few weeks if one of my disc herniates . Opiates can be used safely and effectively , and I am sick and tired of the media and other know - it - alls always stating the opposite . It is precisely because of this misinformation that doctors are now paranoid to treat chronic pain patients and our family doctors have driven us to pain management doctors ( if there are any in your area ! ) where you pee into a little jar every month and spend thousands of dollars per year for basically no reason .

He was using fentanyl. It is an incredibly strong drug. Forgetting that you already took your dose and subsequently you decide to take a second dose (i.e. accidentally taking a double dose) can kill you. A forgetful mistake can kill you with this drug. You will know if someone you know is abusing to Fentanyl. They will likely be incoherent or unconscious. This isn't a drug that's very easy to fake being clean or not addicted.
